narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Dana Graef
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  She was very nice, very engaged and knowledgeable. She was very accessible to students! All thumbs up :)
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana Graef
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana Graef
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana Graef

Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana was a phenomenal resource. She made herself accessible for office hours, and always provided interesting insights and questions during lecture. I especially enjoyed reading a few chapters of her dissertation, and when she lectured as it gave a glimpse into the content and the process of developing a doctoral dissertation.
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana Graef

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course opens eyes and is a MUST for anybody taking responsibility over society in an international context or in other countries!

This is a fantastic course. I loved the readings and found the in-class discussion (as well as Carpenter's lectures) very interesting. The ideas in the class really helped to shape my thinking about the areas I'm interested in. This was, by far, my favorite class at FES this semester.

The course was great in introducing a theoretical framework for unpacking development work that we've all encountered in various periods of our studies and work. The structure of the class was also helpful, with the first half as lecture and second as discussion, where discussion is led by students.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Everything :)The process I went through during the course of this semester!

This course gives you a solid foundation in the literature that discusses conservation and development projects. Dr. Carpenter is excellent at explaining the material and the student led discussions (and sentences required every week) allowed students to try analyzing the materials themselves.
The critical social theories were very valuable in confronting today's environmental and development challenges, especially in discerning false solutions.
The readings and application of the concepts to the final paper.
I appreciated that Professor Carpenter focused showing how Foucault's theories of power, discourse, governmentality, etc. inform contemporary analysis of development and conservation programs.
Coverage from an anthropological perspective of many of the major problems with development. Really important perspectives-- reading in detail many important, foundational authors.
The discussions.

Class readings, lectures, and discussions helped me think critically about development and conservation projects. I now see these projects through a different lens and will be more critical and cautious when implementing projects in the future.I liked the format of the course, with readings being the foundation of class lecture and discussion, but also allowing class lecture and discussion to expand beyond the readings.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The literature focuses on Asia and Africa. I would have been interested in more literature on Latin America.

Some of the readings are really poorly written--Mosse in particular. Most of the readings are very much chosen from Carole's perspective, and I would like to have a few more pieces for contrast. This course is about a certain perspective, and it's not that you can't have any other ideas, but they won't necessarily make any difference in class.
I would have liked to see some more urban-related readings, especially given the growing amount of interest in urban environmental issues.

Some of the readings were dense and difficult to get through. I think some of these readings could be substituted with more practical and applied readings. I particularly liked readings about specific projects, so it might be helpful to have more of these readings.While there are no projects that have not had some negative impacts, I would have liked to read about the positive impacts of some projects/case studies and examine how those positive impacts were achieved, in order to help me envision what strategies can have some success in achieving positive social and environmental impacts.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I appreciated that the discussion leaders met before class with Dana to discuss the readings and better form our discussion questions.
Great format of lecture/talking/CC's perspective, then student-led discussion.
Yes, it was effective.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Dana was good, very responsive, but didn't participate a ton in class. That was actually ok....and gave a little balance to CC.

Dana was wonderful! As noted above, she was great as a lecturer (which she did our final session), as well as a point of reference to elucidate some of the tougher concepts in the readings. She also provided thoughtful feedback on our writing assignments.

Dana was extremely helpful in helping me prepare for leading class discussions, as well as giving me good advice and guidance in preparing for the finalpaper. She also suggested good literature sources to use in my research.
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana had a clear understanding of the literature and was active and helpful both in discussion and in office hours.

Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Her comments on homework assignment were very constructive. Her questions in discussion with presenters were helpful for the presenters to think carefully about organizing their discussion questions.
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana was an excellent teaching fellow. She was accessible, knowledgable about the material, and had a lot of personal experience to help inform her advice.
Instructor: Dana Johanna Graef  Dana was very supportive, and provided thorough and helpful feedback on our assignments.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course gave me a solid foundation in the topics that are a part of conservation and development. I think that the theories discussed in this course can be drawn upon for any other course taken at F&ES.

I found the introduction to the social science approach to development issues crucial to my interest in the intersection of climate justice and sustainable development. I believe this course has made me a more critical and open-minded thinker and researcher.

I think this course was important for developing my theoretical foundation ,but I'm not sure about the practical application for an MEM. As a development practitioner myself, the final reflection paper was a great exercise.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To understand social implications of technical interventions in other countries. To open my mind for a completely different field of research and to openly discover a field priorly unknown to me.
I took this course to learn about conservation and development literature.
Interest in social/political ecology.
I wanted to better understand the available literature about development and environmental issues.
Interest and background in the topics.
I wanted to gain a more critical perspective of development projects and to better understand essential social science aspects that need to be considered in implementing such projects.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: YEEEESSSSS
This course exceeded expectations.
Yes!
Yes

Yes and No. I wanted to have some possible solutions presented-- not just the anthropologist as hero in all of our readings, and to be given some tools for how to apply these consciousnesses in my own work. It's a very academic, and not neccessarily applied course, though one of the richest parts if discussions with other practitioners.
Yes, and it was helpful to apply and challenge those theoretical frameworks by way of the final paper.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We worked with a group when leading the class discussion. Being a part of the group, allowed me to discuss my ideas and thoughts with a smaller group before leading the entire class in a discussion.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it and do your best in it. You have to live for the course and it will be a crucial experience for your time at F&ES!
Have an open mind about the topics that conservation and development literature covers.
Take the time to read carefully and thoroughly so you can engage in class discussion. Putting thought into your thesis sentences is also very useful when writing the final paper.

Be ready to develop your own opinions separately from Carole's and be willing to accept that you may never agree. She's a nice person, and very smart, but I wasn't going to change the way she thought.

Certainly start the readings ahead of time -- they are quite long, and especially if you are taking it first term, it'd be wise to plan on investing quite a bit of time. Annotating is very helpful, and make sure you're actively reading; instead of focusing on the details, look for the major analytical arguments, the methods, and the way in which the findings relate to the theoretical framework that the author(s) set(s) up in the introduction.
Allow quite a bit of time to do the weekly readings/thesis sentences and to prepare for leading class discussions.
